meanings.def: to allow something to fall by accident; to fall by accident
examples: drop something Be careful not to drop that plate.
drop something + adv./prep. I accidentally dropped my glasses into the water.
drop to something The climber slipped and dropped to his death.
His arms dropped limply to his sides.
drop + adj. Her mouth dropped open in disbelief.
He saw Emma and promptly dropped his tray of drinks.
He slowly dropped to the floor.
(figurative) Her heart dropped like a stone at this news.

meanings.def: to make something fall deliberately; to let yourself fall
examples: drop something You can never be sure whether the planes will be dropping bombs or food parcels.
drop something + adv./prep. Medical supplies are being dropped into the stricken area.
She lifted the bag then dropped it down again.
(British English) He dropped his trousers (= undid them and let them fall).
(North American English) He dropped his pants.
drop (+ adv./prep.) Catch me when I drop.
I dropped to my knees beside her.
The plane came straight in, dropping down to land in a field.
He dropped lightly down onto the lawn beneath.
The cheese drops onto a conveyor underneath.
(figurative) He casually drops the latest buzzwords into the conversation.

meanings.def: to fall down or be no longer able to stand because you are extremely tired
examples: I feel ready to drop.
She expects everyone to work till they drop.
drop + adv./prep. He staggered in and dropped into a chair.

meanings.def: to become or make something weaker, lower or less
examples: The temperature has dropped considerably.
At last the wind dropped.
Error rates have dropped dramatically.
drop to something His voice dropped to a whisper.
The Dutch team have dropped to fifth place.
drop by something The price of shares dropped by 14p.
drop in something (by something) Shares dropped in price by 14p.
drop against something The dollar dropped sharply against the euro.
drop something You must drop your speed in built-up areas.
Car crime in Oxford fell significantly last year.
Car crime fell by about a quarter over a 12-month period.
The number of stolen vehicles dropped from 1 013 to 780, a fall of 26 per cent.
According to this data, 780 vehicles were stolen, 26 per cent down on the previous year.
There was an 11 per cent drop in reported thefts from motor vehicles, from 1 971 to 1 737.
These figures show that, as far as car crime is concerned, the main trend is downwards.
The number of children in the class has dropped from 25 to 18.
The price of oil has dropped significantly.
The temperature rarely drops below 30°C.
Sales are likely to drop further.
Processing costs dropped 30 per cent.
The baby's heart rate had dropped.

meanings.def: to fail to win something
examples: It's a long time since we dropped a game.
They didn't drop any points until halfway through the season.
She dropped the second set but came back to win the match.
He dropped his serve (= failed to win games in which it was his turn to hit the ball first) twice in the first set.

meanings.def: to look down
examples: Her eyes dropped to her lap.
She smiled and let her eyes drop again.

meanings.def: to slope steeply downwards
examples: drop (away) (from something) In front of them the valley dropped sharply away from the road.
drop (away) (into/to something) The land dropped steeply away into a small valley.

meanings.def: to stop so that somebody can get out of a car, etc.; to deliver or leave something in a particular place, especially on the way to somewhere else
examples: drop somebody/something Can you drop me near the bank?
drop somebody/something off You left your jacket, but I can drop it off on my way to work tomorrow.
drop something + adv./prep. Just drop it in the mail when you have time.

meanings.def: to send a short letter or email to somebody
examples: Drop me a line when you get there.
Don't hesitate to drop me an email or give me a call.

meanings.def: to put some text, an icon, etc. into a file, folder or place on a computer screen, using the mouse
examples: You can easily drag and drop files onto your memory stick.

meanings.def: to leave somebody/something out by accident or deliberately
examples: drop somebody/something from something She's been dropped from the team because of injury.
drop somebody/something He spoke with a cockney accent and dropped his aitches (= did not pronounce the letter ‘h’ at the start of words).
She was unceremoniously dropped by her record label.

meanings.def: to stop seeing somebody socially
examples: She's dropped most of her old friends.

meanings.def: to stop doing or discussing something; to not continue with something
examples: I dropped German (= stopped studying it) when I was 14.
Drop everything and come at once!
Look, can we just drop it (= stop talking about it)?
I think we'd better drop the subject.
The police decided to drop the charges against her.
Let's drop the formalities—please call me Mike.
Both countries have agreed to drop border controls.
He suddenly dropped his habitual banter.
The formal grade of Geologist was dropped in favour of Scientific Officer.
When nobody volunteered, the idea was finally dropped altogether.

meanings.def: to say or do something in order to show somebody, in an indirect way, what you are thinking
to let a stitch go off the needle
people stop buying or using the products of a particular industry
examples: The bottom has fallen out of the travel market.

meanings.def: to die or become ill and fall down in very large numbers
examples: People were dropping like flies in the intense heat.

meanings.def: to tell the police or people in authority that somebody has done something wrong
examples: If he finds out who dropped the dime on him, they're in trouble.
I'm worried if I drop a dime on this guy, he'll get fired, which I don't think he really deserves.

meanings.def: to make a mistake and cause something that you are responsible for to fail
examples: Let’s not drop the ball on this.

meanings.def: to say something that offends or embarrasses somebody, although you did not intend to
to suddenly not be able to think clearly; to act in a stupid way because you have lost control over yourself
to die suddenly and unexpectedly
used to tell somebody, rudely, to stop annoying you, interfering, etc.
to stop being careful and preparing yourself for possible danger or difficulty
examples: You can never drop your guard with a two-year-old.
Even when he's winning, he never drops his guard.

meanings.def: to put somebody in an embarrassing situation, especially by telling a secret that you should not have told
to make something the responsibility of another person
examples: They dropped the problem firmly back in my lap.

meanings.def: to mention famous people you know or have met in order to impress others
examples: She found him rather irritating to talk to; all he did was drop names.

meanings.def: somebody has the opportunity to do something pleasant without having made any effort
examples: My dream job just fell into my lap.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody suddenly looked surprised, shocked or disappointed
to do or say nothing more about somebody/something
examples: I suggest we let the matter drop.

meanings.def: to mention somebody/something in a conversation, by accident or as if by accident
examples: He let it drop that the prime minister was a close friend of his.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has finally understood or realized something that they had not understood or realized before
examples: I had to explain the joke to her a couple of times before the penny dropped.

meanings.def: it was extremely quiet
examples: The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

idioms.idiom: you could hear a pin drop
examples: The audience was so quiet you could have heard a pin drop.

meanings.def: a very small amount of liquid that forms a round shape
examples: The first drops of rain fell.
There was a drop of blood on his finger.
a drop of water/oil/sweat
Mix a few drops of milk into the cake mixture.
Large drops of sweat rolled down her face.
She wiped a drop of water from her chin.

meanings.def: a small quantity of a liquid
examples: Could I have a drop more milk in my coffee, please?
She carried it across the room without spilling a drop.
drop of something Would you like a drop of brandy?
I haven't touched a drop (= drunk any alcohol) all evening.
He drained the last drop of beer from the glass.
We mustn't waste a single drop.
He didn't let a drop fall.

meanings.def: a fall or reduction in the amount, level or number of something
examples: drop in something a sharp/steep drop in profits
We've seen a 15 per cent drop in price since May.
a dramatic drop in sales/temperature/market share
They reported a significant drop in passenger traffic.
drop against something The pound has suffered a big drop against the euro.
Car crime in Oxford fell significantly last year.
Car crime fell by about a quarter over a 12-month period.
The number of stolen vehicles dropped from 1 013 to 780, a fall of 26 per cent.
According to this data, 780 vehicles were stolen, 26 per cent down on the previous year.
There was an 11 per cent drop in reported thefts from motor vehicles, from 1 971 to 1 737.
These figures show that, as far as car crime is concerned, the main trend is downwards.
If you want the job, you must be prepared to take a drop in salary.
There was a substantial drop in the number of people out of work last month.

meanings.def: a distance straight down from a high point to a lower point
examples: There was a sheer drop of fifty metres to the rocks below.
There was a twenty-foot drop onto the stones beneath.

meanings.def: a liquid medicine that you put one drop at a time into your eyes, ears or nose
examples: eye drops
Use the drops three times a day.

meanings.def: the act of delivering somebody/something in a vehicle or by plane; the act of dropping something
examples: Aid agencies are organizing food drops to civilians in the war zone.
a parachute drop

meanings.def: a small round sweet of the type mentioned
examples: fruit drops
cough drops (= sweets to help a cough)

meanings.def: immediately; without hesitating
examples: The company can't expect me to move my home and family at the drop of a hat.

meanings.def: an amount of something that is too small or unimportant to make any real difference to a situation
examples: The amount of money raised was a drop in the ocean compared to what we needed.

idioms.idiom: at the drop of a hat
examples: The company can't expect me to move my home and family at the drop of a hat.

examples: The amount of money raised was a drop in the ocean compared to what we needed.
